Deficiency Narrative: During the inspection, it was observed that the operation did not have current medical documentation on file for three children in care as required.
During the inspection, it was observed that the operation did not have current documentation on file for two children in care as required .
The medication record indicated that there were to be twenty-one pills remaining, but the actual pill count was twenty.
During the review of the employee files, it was noted that one employee was missing the required annual trainings.
During the investigation service plans were unable to be reviewed due to the operation not providing records in a timely manner.
Correction Narrative:
The operation sent their compliance plan via email on 6/23/2025. 

Corrective Action Steps:
1. High-Risk Screening: All youth will be assessed for high-risk behaviors at intake. Results will determine need for individualized safety contracts.
2. Safety Contract Template: Develop and implement a standardized safety contract template to be customized per child and signed within 72 hours of intake.
3. Training: All clinical and direct care staff will be trained on how to collaboratively develop and implement safety contracts with youth.
4. Supervisor Review: Director of Compliance will ensure the inclusion of safety contracts in all initial plans for high-risk youth before approval.

Deficiency Narrative: During the investigation service plans were unable to be reviewed due to the operation not providing records in a timely manner.
Correction Narrative:
The operation sent their compliance plan via email on 6/23/2025. 

Corrective Action Steps:
1. IEP/Educational Summary Requirement: Require inclusion of IEPs, assessments, and school records at the time of admission or within 7 days.
2. Educational Section Checklist: Add a service plan checklist item specific to academic needs, school attendance, tutoring, or special education services.
3. Collaboration with School Liaisons: Strengthen communication protocols with LEAs to ensure documentation and recommendations are up to date.
4.QA Monitoring: Director of Compliance will verify that all Initial Service Plans include required educational content before final approval.

Deficiency Narrative: During the investigation service plans were unable to be reviewed due to the operation not providing records in a timely manner.
Correction Narrative:
The operation sent their compliance plan via email on 6/23/2025. The operation provided corrections and an updated record access protocol. 
Corrective Action Steps:
1. Record Access Protocol: Implement a centralized digital record-keeping system (secured and access-controlled) to ensure all active service plans and required documents are stored in a Licensing-ready format.
2. Staff Training: Train all case management and administrative staff on procedures for responding to licensing record requests within one hour.
3. On-Site Licensing File Binder: Create and maintain an on-site binder of all current records required for immediate inspection.
4. QA Oversight: Assign Director of Compliance to conduct random monthly audits to verify file accessibility and completeness.

A staff training was conducted to ensure staff are able to respond to licensing record requests within the required timeframe.

Deficiency Narrative: The child's file was missing the required signed child rights.
Correction Narrative: An email was sent with the following information. In response to the requirement to inform children of their rights, we will develop a standardized process to review the rights of children and their parents within 7 days of admission. A written document outlining these rights will be created and made accessible to all children and parents upon admission. To ensure compliance, we will implement a tracking system via the casebook calendar to verify that rights have been reviewed and documented for each child. We will develop clear guidelines for staff on how to effectively communicate childrens rights and support families during the admission process. Photos were provided

Deficiency Narrative: The child's file was missing the required 90-day service plans when receiving treatment services.
Correction Narrative: In response to the need for timely service plan reviews, we will establish a schedule to review service plans for children receiving treatment services every 90 days from the date of the last service plan. The review process, along with any updates made during the review, will be documented. We will distribute information to staff about the importance of timely service plan reviews, specifically for children with emotional disturbances, autism spectrum disorders, or pervasive developmental disorders. A tracking system will be utilized via the casebook calendar to ensure that all service plan reviews are completed on time and in accordance with established standards. Photos were provided

Deficiency Narrative: The child's file was missing the required signatures.
Correction Narrative: To comply with the citation regarding the initial service plan, we will revise our current documentation to ensure that it includes the signatures of all service planning team members involved in its development. A meeting will be held to emphasize the importance of collaborative input in service plan development. We will implement a checklist to verify that all required signatures are obtained before finalizing the service plan. Regular reviews of service plans will be conducted to ensure compliance and necessary adjustments. Photos were provided

Deficiency Narrative: The last fire inspection was conducted on 09/12/24.
Correction Narrative: To address the citation regarding fire inspections, we will schedule a fire inspection within the next month to ensure compliance with the requirement for annual inspections. Documentation of the inspection date will be maintained for future reference. Additionally, we will establish a reminder system to schedule inspections annually, ensuring they occur within the required timeframe. We will also create informational materials about fire safety protocols to raise awareness among all staff members. A photo was provided

Deficiency Narrative: The last health inspection was competed on 02/24/2023
Correction Narrative: To address the sanitation inspection requirement, we will schedule a sanitation inspection with the local health department within the next month. A record of the inspection results and any corrective actions taken will be maintained to ensure accountability. We will also develop a routine schedule for future sanitation inspections to ensure ongoing compliance with health ordinances. We will provide resources and guidelines for staff to ensure they understand the sanitation standards and practices necessary to maintain a clean and safe environment for children. Photos were provided.

Deficiency Narrative: Serious incident report reviewed didn't include time of incident.
Correction Narrative: To correct the documentation issues noted in the citation, we will enhance our incident reporting protocols to ensure all serious incidents are documented with accurate time and date. Staff will receive training on proper documentation practices, and a standardized incident report form will be introduced. Regular audits will be conducted to ensure compliance and completeness in incident reporting, fostering accountability and improving our overall documentation process

Deficiency Narrative: Staff member yelled and used profane language towards child in care.
Correction Narrative:
To address the citation regarding prohibited punishments, our facility will implement mandatory training for staff on positive behavior support and trauma-informed care. This training will emphasize the harms of humiliating, shaming, or ridiculing children, promoting constructive disciplinary techniques instead. Clear guidelines have been established prohibiting any form of emotional punishment, with regular supervision to ensure compliance. Violations will result in immediate corrective action, and children will be encouraged to voice concerns about staff behavior.

Follow-up Interviews were also conducted

Deficiency Narrative: Investigator had to request the documents three different times.  Originally request 04/18/2024 and not received until 04/24/2024.
Correction Narrative:
An email was sent with the following corrective action. Alijah House is committed to rectifying the recent citation under standard 745.411(b)(4),
which emphasizes the necessity of not delaying or preventing inspections or investigations.
Our corrective action plan we will ensure that all requested documents are supplied within
24 hours of a request. If there's a need to source documents externally, we will request an
extension within the 24-hour period.
To facilitate this, we have assigned a point of contact (KhaRaven Guevara or Tony Rodgers)
to handle document requests and communicate protocols to all staV. We've established a
clear process for document retrieval and trained our staV accordingly. Additionally, a
formal protocol for extension requests is in place. If an extension is needed, we will submit
the request with 24 hours of the initial request of documents.
We will keep a detailed log of all document requests and actions taken, monitor
compliance through regular internal audits, and include standard 745.411(b)(4)
compliance in staV performance evaluations. The plan will be reviewed and adjusted semiannually
to ensure continuous adherence to the residential childcare minimum standards

Deficiency Narrative: Interviews confirm six children were being supervised by one staff. It was reported that an additional staff on shift was in the office until the end of the incident.
Correction Narrative:
Standard 748.1005-Child/caregiver ratio-Each group must have enough caregivers for that
group who are not caring for other children or doing administrative work.
Alijah House staE will keep standard ratio for each group. Care staE will not perform any
administrative work including gathering documents needed to complete daily progress
notes if forms run out.

Follow-up is placed in Chrono.

Deficiency Narrative: An employee was unemployed for a month and was still listed has active in the system.
Correction Narrative:
To ensure timely and accurate validation of background checks for staff members associated with children's services, including the prompt deactivation of individuals who are no longer associated with our operation.
	Steps: Review the existing policy regarding background check validation and the deactivation process for staff members.
	Revise the policy to include clear guidelines and timeframes for validating background checks and deactivating individuals no longer associated with the operation, adhering to the seven-day timeline. Implement a system for documenting background check validation activities and the status of staff members.
	Maintain accurate records of background check expiration dates, validation dates, and deactivation actions.
	Ensure that records are easily accessible and regularly reviewed for compliance. Establish a clear process for notifying relevant personnel, such as HR representatives or department heads, when a staff member leaves the organization.
	Ensure that notifications trigger the initiation of the background check validation and deactivation process within the designated timeframe. Conduct periodic audits or checks to assess the effectiveness of the background check validation and deactivation process.
	Identify any areas of non-compliance or opportunities for improvement.
	Take corrective actions as necessary to address issues and enhance the overall effectiveness of the process. Foster a culture of continuous improvement by soliciting feedback from staff members and licensing reps regarding the background check validation and deactivation process.
	Use feedback to identify areas for enhancement and implement changes as appropriate.
By implementing this corrective action plan, we aim to ensure compliance with standard rule 745.651(1) regarding background check validation and the timely deactivation of individuals who are no longer associated with our operation. This will help mitigate potential risks and maintain the integrity of our children's services programs.

Deficiency Narrative: One out of three youth files reviewed did not include suicide screening documentation.
Correction Narrative:
To implement policies and procedures for conducting suicide screening during admissions for children at Alijah House, in compliance with standard rule 748.1205 sub-category(a)(14)
	Review existing admission policies and procedures to assess the inclusion of suicide screening protocols.
	Develop a comprehensive policy specifically addressing suicide screening at admissions, outlining the screening tool to be utilized and the process for administration. Research and select a validated suicide screening tool appropriate for children's admissions.
	Ensure that the selected screening tool aligns with best practices in suicide risk assessment and is sensitive to the needs of children. Provide training to admissions staff on the implementation of the suicide screening tool.
	Educate staff on recognizing signs of suicidal ideation and appropriate responses during the admissions process.
	Ensure that staff members are equipped with the knowledge and skills necessary to conduct screenings sensitively and effectively. Integrate the suicide screening process seamlessly into the existing admissions workflow.
	Determine the optimal timing and context for administering the screening tool to ensure thorough assessment while respecting the child's privacy and comfort
	Establish protocols for documenting the results of suicide screenings in the child's admission records.
	Ensure that screening documentation is thorough, accurate, and maintained in a secure and confidential manner.
	Implement mechanisms for securely storing and accessing screening records in compliance with privacy regulations. Develop a clear protocol for responding to positive suicide screens during the admissions process.
	Define roles and responsibilities for staff members involved in responding to and addressing suicidal risk.
	Establish procedures for immediate intervention, including contacting appropriate mental health professionals and ensuring the safety and well-being of the child. Implement mechanisms for ongoing monitoring and evaluation of the suicide screening process.
	Collect feedback from staff members and stakeholders regarding the effectiveness and feasibility of the screening procedures.
	Regularly review screening data and outcomes to identify trends, areas for improvement, and opportunities to enhance the process. Conduct regular audits or reviews to assess compliance with the suicide screening policy and procedures.
	Generate reports summarizing screening outcomes, response protocols, and any identified areas for improvement.
	Provide reports to relevant stakeholders, regulatory agencies, or accreditation bodies as required
By implementing this corrective action plan, Alijah House aims to ensure the effective implementation of suicide screening protocols during admissions, thereby promoting the safety and well-being of children under our care and ensuring compliance with standard rule 748.1205 sub-category(a)(14)

Deficiency Narrative: Two out of three child files reviewed had primary medical consenters that are no longer employed at the facility.
Correction Narrative:
Correctives: Ensure placement agreements include a medical consent form signed by a person legally authorized by the Texas Family Code to provide consent, in compliance with 748.1207(a)(2).
Action Steps
1.
Review and Identify Gaps:

Immediately review existing placement agreements to identify gaps in including the required medical consent form.
2.
Policy Update:

Update policies and procedures to explicitly mandate the inclusion of the medical consent form in all placement agreements.
3.
Training and Awareness:

Conduct training sessions for staff on the importance of including the medical consent form in placement agreements.

Raise awareness among staff about the legal requirements under the Texas Family Code.
4.
Template Revision:

Revise placement agreement templates to include a specific section for the medical consent form.

Ensure the language aligns with legal requirements.
5.
Legal Consultation:

Seek legal consultation to confirm the appropriateness and completeness of the medical consent form language.
6.
Communication with Authorized Individuals:

Establish clear communication channels with individuals legally authorized under the Texas Family Code to provide consent.

Provide necessary information and documentation requirements to facilitate timely consent.
7.
Recordkeeping and Audits:

Implement a robust recordkeeping system to track the inclusion of medical consent forms in placement agreements.

Conduct regular internal audits to ensure ongoing compliance.
8.
Immediate Corrections:

Develop a protocol for immediate correction if a placement agreement is identified without the required medical consent form.
9.
Ongoing Compliance Checks:

Integrate regular compliance checks into the placement agreement review process to prevent future lapses.
10.
Feedback Loop:

Establish a feedback loop for staff to report any challenges or concerns related to including the medical consent form.

Use feedback to continuously improve the implementation of the corrective action plan.
This corrective action plan emphasizes immediate review, policy updates, staff training, and ongoing compliance measures to rectify and prevent non-compliance with the placement agreement requirement at Alijah House Children Services.

Also attached were updated Attachemennt B forms.

Deficiency Narrative: Licensing waited for over an hour for the LCCA and/or staff to arrive at the facility for the inspection.
Correction Narrative:
Correctives:To ensure that responsibilities are attended to promptly without delaying or preventing inspections or investigations by having a designated individual available at the facility or within a 30-minute response time.
Action Steps: 1. Designate On-site Staff: Identify and designate responsible staff members who will be present at the facility during operational hours and who can respond within 30 minutes during non-operational hours. 2. Establish Contact Protocols: Implement a communication system that ensures designated staff members can be reached promptly in case of inspections, investigations, or urgent matters. 3. Training and Awareness: Conduct training sessions to educate all staff about the importance of timely response to inspections or investigations, emphasizing their roles and responsibilities. 4. Rotation Schedule: Develop a rotation schedule to ensure adequate coverage at all times, including weekends, holidays, and after business hours, ensuring there's always someone available or reachable within the specified time frame. 5. Contingency Plans: Develop contingency plans for situations where designated staff members might be unavailable due to unforeseen circumstances. This may include designated alternates or clear escalation procedures. 6. Review and Adaptation: Regularly review the effectiveness of the plan and make necessary adjustments based on feedback, changes in staff, or any incidents that occur.
By implementing this corrective action plan, Alijah House Children Services can ensure compliance with the specified standard, maintaining operational readiness for inspections and investigations without delay.

Deficiency Narrative: The child in care did not take the medication as prescribed. The child has not taken the medication Amantadine 100mg since 11/28/23.
Correction Narrative:
Correctives: To ensure accurate administration of prescription medication, verify children take medications as prescribed, and maintain a timely refill process. Additionally, to address situations where refills cannot be obtained, requiring an emergency medication review by a psychiatrist, even if an appointment is scheduled for a later date, in compliance with standard rule 748.2003(B)(5).
Action Steps: 1. Medication Request Protocol: - Establish a standardized procedure for medication requests ensuring they are made within a specified time frame prior to the end of the prescription period. - Train staff to accurately communicate and document medication requests promptly. 2. Refill Management: - Initiate refills within one week of the ending prescription to allow sufficient time for processing and administration continuity. - Implement a tracking system to monitor refill status and ensure timely refills. 3. Emergency Refill Situations: - Develop a protocol for scenarios where a refill cannot be filled. - Mandate an immediate call to the prescribing psychiatrist for an emergency medication review, regardless of any previously scheduled appointments, as stipulated by standard rule 748.2003(B)(5). 4. Psychiatrist Engagement: - Educate staff about the critical importance of promptly engaging the psychiatrist in emergency refill situations. - Establish clear communication channels for emergency consultations with the psychiatrist. 5. Documentation and Reporting: - Create a comprehensive documentation process to record all medication administration, refill requests, and emergency situations requiring psychiatrist involvement. - Establish a reporting system to monitor the effectiveness of the protocol and identify potential issues. 6. Regular Review and Adaptation: - Conduct regular reviews of the protocol's effectiveness and make necessary adjustments based on feedback, changing circumstances, or encountered incidents, ensuring continuous compliance with standard rule 748.2003(B)(5).
By implementing and adhering to this protocol, Alijah House Children's Services will ensure compliance with standard rule 748.2003(B)(5) while facilitating accurate medication administration, timely refills, and appropriate emergency actions when refills cannot be obtained. This will contribute significantly to the safety and well-being of the children under care.
